title: My Little Contribution to the Estuary Discussion

transcript_parts.text: well that connection has kicked me out
of the Estuary meeting so I figured I'll
just get my
two cents about what was going on in the
conversation so far
um and post it later
um I think that the narrative way of
looking at life is definitely the thing
that makes the most sense it's really
inescapable for people when we
communicate with each other that's how
we communicate even when we talk about
abstract things we still describe them
in some sort of a narrative we still
have to
deal with chronolog chronological
Frameworks when we explain facts and
things and so
that is the right way to look at life
but the problems are we don't know what
character we are and we don't know what
kind of narrative it is
and so the frame issue is the issue of
trying to figure out what the narrative
is and we we also have to deal with the
fact that our tools for this for
discovering who we are and what our
story is are limited and that's why we
need to
collaborate with others to
figure it out
um
but
as far as figuring out the story we're
in you know if we are too um
too disheartened by
the faults in our ability to
perceive the frame that we look at
things through then you know we just
become full of
nihilism you know everything is
meaningless or it's unknowable and so it
doesn't really matter
um
of course if we
think that the story is like some kind
of a hero's journey
and we think that we are the central
character then we can become
narcissistic
and so I think the the wisest thing to
do is to assume we're not the central
figure
and from a Christian standpoint of
course
we would say that Jesus is the central
character in this story that we are a
part of
but
when we focus on the hero
um and and realize that we are not the
hero we think
that you know that brings us to the the
problem of what what are we doing what
is what is my purpose what makes my life
meaningful and
um I think that
we
ignore a lot of the necessity of the
small details
in these stories
um like does the hero make his own shoes
probably not so somebody was in charge
of that and the story needs that person
um
you know the same thing who makes his
meals who
takes care of all the the material stuff
the mundane things that create the
setting for the hero to
work in and be in
but another thing I think is to realize
that although we see Jesus as a central
character of ours of the story within
the gospels he also says that
when anyone uh gives a cup of water to
someone who's thirsty they've done it
unto me and so Jesus is present not only
as the hero but as
the people that the hero rescues in a
sense and if we can assist in that then
we become the hero
and it's it's no less of a significant
way we become a hero to that person but
we're also
becoming a hero by supporting
the hero because we're doing it not just
to that person but to Jesus and so we
help him to accomplish the goals and the
tasks that he's trying to do
and I think that if we look at that and
we use the right tools and we we
communicate with others to figure out
where what the right frame is and what
our place is and that it will bring
meaning even to the mundane things of
life and I think that's the
